_@ben.j.targett has joined the channel_
_@jonathonwilson92 has joined the channel_

Hey Benedict, please meet Jonathon your incredible E-Mentor we've been telling you about :smile:.  Feel free to introduce yourselves, say a little bit about what you would like to get out of the mentorship and continue chatting within this channel. :wave:

I will now be leaving the channel, but please direct message myself or penny-prospela if you have any questions. All the best for now! :slightly_smiling_face:
_@emma has left the channel_
_@emma has left the channel_

Hello! Thanks for doing this. I have never been part of a mentorship before, so not sure exactly how this works, but still excited.

I must admit I have never played the mafia games, working at Hangar 13 I assume this is the main series you have worked on. I could always download the demo of 3 if you think it would be helpful.

Anyhow nice to meet you. Would it be useful to send you some of my work?

Hi, no problem at all I’m happy to help where I can. Mentorships can take many forms but ultimately I’m here to offer advice and guidance where I can and obviously answer any questions you might have about the industry. 

Don’t worry about not having played Mafia 3. I joined the company after that project had shipped. 

Before you start sending over work for me to look at. I think it would be better to know what it is you’re looking for, what your actively doing at the minute and any questions you might have at this point.

What I am looking for in terms of the mentorship, I think mainly is someone to check my stuff, and tell me how I can improve. or give me tips for how I could present myself better, and if what I am doing is relevent to the industry. Stuff like that.

In terms of my projects at the moment, I am mainly doing coursework for Uni. The current project is to create a GDD and accompanying demo's for the game. I have decided to try and essentially create a mechanics and level design demo by simply making one of the levels from my game. At the moment I developing the mechanics with unity, trying to get them all working smoothly with one another.

I am also trying to learn substance painter/designer in my spare time, I have done a lot of designer and only a little bit of painter. It would be great if you have any experience with those, to have some feedback on my substance designer materials.

It would be great to know a bit more about you as well. The formatting on the profile they sent me was broken, so I could only get few things. If I understand your main field is level design, what kind of stuff do you do day to day in your job?

That seems fair and usually what happens during mentorships through various conversations etc.

The Uni project sounds good and you seem to have accounted for scope in how you plan to approach it too. I'm glad to see this has you mixing both design and development/implementation. As much Unity knowledge you can get the better to honest. Even if you end up working with something else in the future the development practices and understanding are quite transferable.

I know at uni you will try your hand at a little bit of everything but its important to think about what it is you would prefer to do. Art, design, Programming etc. In smaller companies you might end up doing other things outside you main discipline, but it good to know which area think you would like to go into most.

Yeah, I have heard the focus a lot, currently I am really enjoying environmental art, texturing , stuff like that. Also trying to fit in learning shader development, with the aim to integrate that with my environmental work.

Thing is, my dream is to start my own company, so I am trying to learn a  bit of everything, Ideally while still remaining employable... I dont know if you think thats dumb, and I should just focus on one thing anyway?

Its not dumb at all. When I was in Uni I had to turn my hand to a little bit of everything a little bit like you're now. I was able to focus in the area of game/level design fully until I joined a team. If art is the thing that calls to you most right now thats good and I would recommend honing in on that. Complementing your art with a understanding of shader is good at this point and it might be something you really enjoy. One thing to remember with shader though is that fall more in to tech art than environmental art.

Wanting to start your own company is a good dream and something to work towards. One thing I would recommend though is possibly working somewhere first just to get a bit of experience so you can see how active development actually works.  Working for a company also provide a sort of safety net for you too while your still learning.

I will try to better summaries my career history so far since the profile you received didn't come through great.  For now here is my Linkedin:
<https://www.linkedin.com/in/jonathon-wilson-6b12455a/>
It doesnt need to be anything crazy, it would just be interesting to see what kind of work you do. 0:)
Don't worry I know lol I will just give you a run down of my roles/progression. It will probably be after work though now.
